results.title: New York: City of Cities
results.creator_credit: Peter May, Jerilyn Goodman, Producers Group and International Video Network
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
There’s no city on earth like New York. Start with the Statue of Liberty, welcoming beacon to millions of immigrants; continue on to Wall Street, seat of the stock exchange and quiet Trinity Church. Jostle through the garment district, gawk at the world’s tallest skyscrapers, and have a guided tour of NBC. Go inside the Metropolitan Museum to see the works of Van Gogh, Gauguin and Warhol, then continue on to the Guggenheim, Lincoln Centre, and Radio City Music Hall. Proceed to Broadway and Sardi’s Restaurant, with its walls of celebrity caricatures. Ride through Central Park in a horse-drawn carriage, then visit the United Nations. Enjoy the atmosphere of Chinatown, Greenwich Village, Little Italy, and Soho.

results.title: Impressions of Hong Kong and Macau
results.creator_credit: James Omi, Patrick Sun and Video Postcard Souvenirs
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Jetfoils and junks, sampans and ferries skim across the harbour as you begin your visit to Hong Kong. Push through the crowded streets of this bustling financial centre and enjoy the folk theatre performances going on all around. Shop in the street markets and elegant department stores. Enjoy a change of pace in the outer islands, dotted with quiet fishing villages, serene monasteries and isolated beaches. Visit Macau, the oldest European settlement in Asia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Omi, Patrick Sun and Video Postcard Souvenirs

results.title: Germany: A Tapestry of Tradition
results.creator_credit: James R. Conner and Heumann-Reiss Production Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Visit West Germany, land of castles and kings, cathedrals and alpine peaks. Experience the quiet mystery of the Black Forest. Watch a craftsman carve a violin in the village of Mittenwald. Continue on to the awe-inspiring Gothic cathedrals of Wurzburg, Ettal and Nymphenburg. See the fairytale castle of Neuschwanstein, built by eccentric King Ludwig II, come alive. Then, join in the celebration of Munich’s Oktoberfest!

results.title: Discovering China and Tibet
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Discover China, the 5,000-year-old “Middle Kingdom” and mysterious Tibet. The journey begins in Beijing, home to Chinese emperors for more than 500 years. Travel to Xian, the ancient capital, to examine a Neolithic village. Visit the birthplace of Confucius, then trek to Tibet’s mountainous land shrouded in Buddhist culture. Witness the effects of modernisation on the Chinese workplace that has transformed China into an awakening giant.

results.title: Great Cities of Europe
results.creator_credit: James R. Conner, International Video Network, Calcon, Valentini and Adler Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Enjoy a grand tour of Europe’s most renowned cities: London, Dublin, Amsterdam, Munich, Vienna, Salzburg, Paris, Madrid, Athens and Rome. See romantic castles, picturesque canals, lively piazzas and splendid parks; meet the Europeans at work and play.

results.title: The Good years of jazz
results.creator_credit: Bernard Rubin, Mike Bryan and Storyville Films
results.brief_description: In the early 1960’s, the Goodyear tyre company comissioned five short jazz films, featuring a handful of the leading musicians of the day in a move that was not purely philanthropic, but which also acted as part of a promotional campaign.

group_works.title: The Louis Armstrong All-Stars
group_works.creator_credit: Bernard Rubin, Mike Bryan and Storyville Films

results.title: Duke Ellington and his orchestra
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Good years of jazz”.
Features one of the most famous jazz musicians of our time, Duke Ellington leads his orchestra in some his most popular hits. These include: ‘Take the A train, satin Doll, Blow by blow, Things ain’t what they used to be, VIP boogie and Kinda Dukish.’ Ample time is given to solo performances by many of the fine soloists.

results.title: The Louis Armstrong All-Stars
results.creator_credit: Bernard Rubin, Mike Bryan and Storyville Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Good years of jazz”.
Recorded in New York City in 1962 as part of a jazz promotion sponsored by Good Year, this film features a great band playing popular jazz standards. Joining Armstrong on trumpet are Trummy Young on trombone, Billy Kyle on piano and the fabulous Jewel Brown on vocals. Armstrong plays “C’est Si Bon”, “Someday”, “Nobody Knows the Trouble I’ve Seen” and a rousing finale of “When the Saints Go Marching In”.

results.title: Travel tips
results.creator_credit: David McKenzie and Associated Television International
results.brief_description: Noted travel expert Laura Mckenzie takes us to various tourist destinations around the world. As well as suggesting places to visit, she also gives tips on clothing, climate, local customs, prices, accomodation, opening hours, etc.

results.title: London
results.creator_credit: David McKenzie and Associated Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel tips”.
How do I get around in a city like London? What type of coat should I pack? What is the best time to see the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace? Where’s an old English pub? Where should I go outside of London? These are just some of the questions travel expert Laura McKenzie answers in this fascinating tour of London. Included are day trips to Windsor Castle, Blenheim Palace, Stratford-upon-Avon, Ragley Hall and Warwick Castle.
